questions.text: A 76-year-old Japanese man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-month history of loose stools and worsening peripheral edema. He also reports fatigue, a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 weeks, and a tingling sensation in his hands and feet over the same time period. Aside from the family dog, he has not had contact with animals for over 1 year and has not traveled outside the country. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Two years ago, he underwent a partial gastrectomy with jejunal anastomosis for gastric cancer. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and tamsulosin. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 132/83 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. There is a well-healed scar on the upper abdomen. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The conjunctivae appear pale. Sensation to vibration and position is absent over the lower extremities. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.9 g/dL, MCV is 108 μm3, total protein 3.9 g/dL, and albumin 1.9 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a history of gastric cancer with a partial gastrectomy, and recurrence of the cancer in the remnant stomach can occur. Gastric cancer is usually asymptomatic in early stages but may become symptomatic in later stages and manifest with weight loss, anemia, abdominal pain, and dysphagia. While the patient's weight loss, fatigue, and anemia could be associated with malignancy, the signs of malabsorption (i.e., diarrhea, vitamin B12 deficiency, and hypoalbuminemia) are less likely to be due to cancer recurrence.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased intestinal motility is often seen in infections of the gastrointestinal tract. Patients typically present acutely with diarrhea, watery or unformed stools, abdominal pain, or fever. The extended course of this patient's symptoms over 3 months and the lack of fever, abdominal pain, and any food known to be contaminated or travel exposure make this diagnosis unlikely. Also, a gastrointestinal infection would not explain the peripheral edema seen in this patient. The most likely diagnosis in this case is associated with locally decreased intestinal motility.

C) CORRECT:

Blind loop syndrome is a type of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) that develops in patients who have a blind intestinal loop following abdominal surgery (e.g., subtotal gastrectomy with Roux-en-Y, Billroth II). A blind pouch that is no longer connected to the stomach results in locally decreased intestinal motility and a relative lack of acidity, both of which result in excessive growth and colonization of the intestinal flora. This overgrowth of bacteria results in the formation of loose and/or fatty stools and, in some cases, malabsorption. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a common manifestation of SIBO and is a result of both malabsorption and increased uptake of the vitamin by the bacteria.

SIBO can be diagnosed with endoscopic cultures from the jejunum (gold standard) or a positive lactulose breath test. Treatment options include an elemental diet, correction of nutrient or micronutrient deficiencies, antibiotics, or probiotics. In rare cases, surgical correction of the reconstruction may be necessary.
Image Description:

Subtotal gastrectomy:
- Subtotal gastrectomy involves the resection of the body and pyloric channel of the stomach (transparent portion of the stomach in this image).
- The cardia and fundus of the stomach and their blood supply is preserved (opaque portion of the stomach here).
- The duodenal stump (dashed red line) is closed.

Roux-en-Y anastomosis:
- A segment of the proximal jejunum is divided.
- Gastrojejunostomy creation: The distal cut end of the jejunal loop (black I) is anastomosed side-to-side to the gastric stump (purple dashed line; I–I).
- Jejunojejunostomy creation: The proximal jejunal stump (green II) is anastomosed end-to-side to a distal jejunal loop (green dashed line, II–II).

D) INCORRECT:

Bypass of the pyloric sphincter with rapid gastric emptying after a reconstructive gastrointestinal procedure (e.g., Roux-en-Y, Billroth II) can result in dumping syndromes. Early dumping and late dumping both manifest with gastrointestinal pain, nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea following a meal. Palpitations and diaphoresis or shakiness and hypoglycemia may also be present. While the loose stools described here could also occur in dumping syndrome, findings of malabsorption and the fact that this patient's symptoms are not associated with meals make it an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Anastomotic stricture can occur at surgically created anastomoses in the gastrointestinal tract. Patients with an anastomotic stricture typically present with obstipation, frequent small bowel movements, or bloating, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's loose stools and malabsorption are not consistent with a stricture. Additionally, most anastomotic strictures tend to occur within the first year after surgery.
questions.hint: This patient's gastrointestinal tract was anatomically altered through a reconstructive procedure, resulting in an anastomosis between the remaining stomach and the jejunum that has led to the formation of a blind duodenal pouch. The patient now presents with symptoms of malabsorption, including diarrhea, vitamin B12 deficiency (anemia, paresthesias, loss of vibratory sensation and proprioception), hypoalbuminemia (peripheral edema), and weight loss, all of which suggest blind loop syndrome.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with a long history of type 2 diabetes reports a 3-month history of diarrhea, bloating, abdominal fullness, and early satiety. She reports no association with dietary triggers, such as dairy products. She has no recent history of antibiotic use or travel.
Physical examination reveals abdominal distention. Stool studies reveal no infectious etiology, and upper endoscopy and colonoscopy reveal only normal mucosa.
Laboratory testing reveals a hematocrit of 38.0% (reference range, 36.0–46.0) with macrocytosis. The patient’s glycated hemoglobin level is 7.0%. An iron panel is normal. The serum B12 level is 241 pg/mL (> 250), and the serum folate level is > 20.0 ng/mL (3.1–17.5).
Vitamin B12 supplementation is given.
Which one of the following treatments is best for this patient’s ongoing diarrhea?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Persistent bloating in the setting of long-standing type 2 diabetes should prompt suspicion for impaired gastrointestinal motility, which puts patients at risk for small-intestine bacterial overgrowth. Laboratory findings in small intestinal bacterial overgrowth typically show macrocytosis, with elevated serum folate levels and a B12 level at the lower limit of normal, because the bacteria consume dietary B12 and release folate as a by-product. Effective antibiotic therapy should cover aerobic and anaerobic enteric bacteria. A wide range of antibiotics can be used, including ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, or amoxicillin-clavulanate, but the preferred agent is rifaximin. This drug has demonstrated superior efficacy in many randomized studies and is not absorbed systemically.

Key learning point: The recommended treatment for bacterial overgrowth of the small intestine is rifaximin.

B) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet would not address the issue of bacterial growth. Celiac disease, which would be appropriately treated with a gluten-free diet, is associated with folate deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Although improved diabetes control would help prevent continued nerve damage to the enteric nervous system, it will not solve the acute issue of bacterial overgrowth. In addition, this patient has reasonable control of her diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance can cause bloating but is not typically associated with macrocytosis, an elevated folate level and a low level of vitamin B12.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic insufficiency would not be expected to cause the metabolic profile seen in this patient, unless the pancreatic insufficiency were severe, preventing breakdown of the protein-B12 complex and leading to poor absorption.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of bloating, flatulence, and crampy abdominal pain with alternating diarrhea and constipation. Her primary care physician prescribed simethicone 2 weeks ago with no improvement, prompting her visit to the emergency department. She has a history of type 2 diabetes, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and chronic back pain. Her regular medications are metformin, omeprazole, and oxycodone with no changes in the past year. Her last routine colonoscopy 3 years ago was normal. She denies fever, night sweats, or weight loss. She has not noted any blood or melena in her stool. Recent outpatient laboratory studies showed normal CBC, complete metabolic panel, and iron profile, with borderline low vitamin B12, high folate, and HbA1c 8.9%. Vital signs are BP, 138/82 mm Hg; P, 88; R, 16; T, 37°C (98.6°F); and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distension without tenderness. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has multiple risk factors for small intestinal bacterial overgrowth. In addition to achlorhydria from proton pump inhibitor use, her intestinal motility may be impaired due to opioid use and autonomic neuropathy related to her uncontrolled diabetes. The combination of typical gastrointestinal symptoms (bloating, flatulence, alternating bowel habits) with the characteristic laboratory pattern of low vitamin B12 and elevated folate strongly suggests small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO). While her borderline low B12 could also be related to metformin and proton pump inhibitor use, the elevated folate suggests bacterial synthesis of folate by the overgrown intestinal bacteria. Hydrogen breath testing is the preferred confirmatory test and appropriate for outpatient referral.

B) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen is not indicated in this patient with a chronic, stable symptom pattern, normal vital signs, and no signs of acute abdomen on examination. Her presentation lacks features suggestive of acute pathology, obstruction, or inflammatory processes that would warrant immediate imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

A laxative is not appropriate for this patient with alternating diarrhea and constipation, as it could worsen diarrheal episodes and does not address the underlying cause of her symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is not indicated at this point, given that this patient's last screening colonoscopy was normal only 3 years ago. Beyond the changes in bowel habits, she does not have other red flags for colorectal cancer such as weight loss, blood in the stool, or iron-deficiency anemia, and her presentation predominantly suggests small bowel pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Fecal calprotectin is a marker of intestinal inflammation used primarily to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease from functional disorders. This patient's presentation lacks features of active intestinal inflammation such as fever, weight loss, bloody stools, or systemic symptoms. Another management step is more appropriate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with Crohn disease and prior ileocecal resection presents with a 4-month history of bloating, flatulence, and loose stools. Vital signs are BP, 126/78; P, 88; R, 16; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows mild abdominal distension without tenderness. Laboratory studies show elevated folate levels, low vitamin B12, and normal C-reactive protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease flare typically manifests with inflammatory symptoms, including low-grade fever, abdominal tenderness, and with elevated inflammatory markers. The normal C-reactive protein level and absence of fever or tenderness make active inflammatory bowel disease less likely. The elevated folate level is also not characteristic of Crohn disease flares.

B) INCORRECT:

Celiac disease causes malabsorption but typically results in low folate levels rather than elevated levels. This combination of low vitamin B12 and elevated folate is not characteristic of celiac disease, which usually causes deficiencies in multiple micronutrients.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic insufficiency can cause malabsorption with bloating and loose stools. However, this condition typically results in deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins and does not characteristically cause elevated folate levels. This specific pattern of elevated folate with low vitamin B12 deficiency is not typical of pancreatic insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Short bowel syndrome typically occurs with extensive bowel resection and manifests with more severe manifestations of malabsorption, such as diarrhea, dehydration, and electrolyte abnormalities. The specific pattern of elevated folate with low B12 deficiency is more characteristic of another condition, which can occur secondary to or independently of short bowel syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has significant risk factors (prior ileocecal resection, possible adhesions and/or strictures due to Crohn disease) and classic symptoms of bloating, flatulence, and loose stools without inflammatory signs. The characteristic laboratory pattern of elevated folate and low vitamin B12 results from bacterial synthesis of folate which is then absorbed by the intestine and from competitive uptake of vitamin B12 by bacteria.
